title: Ontology-Driven Unified Governance in Software Engineering: The PoolParty case study

author: Monika Solanki, Department of Computer Science, University of Oxford

segmentation: This work has been done in collaboration with the Semantic Web Company Christian, who's My coauthor is here as well, and the idea behind this work is to show how ontologies can contribute towards driving governance in software engineering lifecycles.
The term unified governance was defined in the Align Project, and it denotes the capturing of knowledge of software engineering processes in a typical software development lifecycle.
Always you have information coming from various sources and how a common ontology can be used to integrate this information and govern, and then you can govern it.
For example, create and then knew knowledge can be inferred in a unified way.
So anyone who has worked on Big Data Systems in a collaborative way would know that bridging the gap between software and big data engineering is a hard problem.
And to make our lives easy.
We have a collaborative software development environments like GitHub, Jira, all around us and they actually allow us to work in a more dynamic and agile fashion in the process.
What happens that the development of software itself becomes a very complex activity so you have teams of developers, testers who are involved in discussions.
So if you have client requirements coming in, there are lots of deliberations, lots of iterations and lots of discussions happening before.
A design decision is reached.
The problem is that all these deliberations and discussions, even though they might, if they are at all recorded, they would be recorded as unstructured text so.

All while they are very useful and helpful for us collaborative software development environments have certain limitations, so the two useful things I mean that we could, you know in terms of limitations that we could pick up from these environments, is one that they have very generic field.
So GitHub has something like an issue, that's it.
So what that issue is about, and in response to an issue, you can give a comment so you can provide a comment, but there is no way where you can say that this is a specific type of an issue.
Or the comment that I'm making is actually in support of an argument that was previously made, or it's again something that was said, you know, somewhere up in the thread.

The other thing is that when you have requirements and you have issues, implementation issues that are generated when these requirements are implemented, there is no unified interface where you can link these two and see which were the issues raised against a specific requirement.
So what this work does is it proposes an ontology driven approach where you where you capture information from the various processes that are involved in a typical software development lifecycle.
So there is a development of the software itself.
There is the maintenance and the implementation, and then how this and then we show how this this anthology can be used to.
Then you know, provide a unified governance framework so that that.
Aggregated information can be queried.

We apply this to an industrial use case, which is the development of the pool party Thesaurus server, which is the taxonomy management software and the result of this application is a graph search powered unified governance dashboard, which which provides you a nice visualization over the integrated and aggregated information.

So the motivating scenario for us is the current setup in the semantic Web company where you know they are developing the pool party product and what as most typical software development companies do, they record their requirements in Confluence an when they implement those requirements in a particular version of pool party.
The implementation issues get recorded in G Rob, now each.
The JIRA is also used by the team members in the Semantic Web company customers for issue.
An change tracking as different versions of pool party are released and internally it is used.
Also used by team members for organizer ideas for organizing the ideas around how a specific issue can be implemented or resolved so they follow an agile.
A typical agile methodology where data the data that is recorded in confluence is recorded as a requirement.
A goal there is a user story.
There is an epic and stakeholder, so anyone who has done a child development would be familiar with these terms.
The additional context to this agile development is provided by things such as precondition, detailed description, the acceptance criteria and the test scenario.
So, given a specific implementation, what would you use to characterize it further?
And there is one single field comment.
That you can you know, use to provide all your thoughts or all your ideas about a specific thing that is being discussed.

That will enhance your search experience.
So we take all of this and then we integrate that information and finally we put it into a triple store and they also persisted as a file.

I mean, structuring the information has made a big impact, but when we did the math behind it, when we actually put things together and did the computation, which you will find on that Google Doc and which I have time, I'll show we found that there was actually a 50% increase in the search over structured data set, and this was one of the things Semantic Web Company wanted to do for a very long time.
They were.
Always using the conventional keyword search from conference in JIRA and they wanted to convert that into linked data so that they could enhance the search experience.
This would save them resources from a developer perspective and save them a lot of time in hunting for issues corresponding to a requirement.
So the analysis that emerged from this was that the overall time taken to search the structured data is 50% less when compared to the time taken to search confluence and JIRA.
It also highlighted the weakness of the full text search, so we are not there yet.
So when it comes to searching.
Over structured data.
For information.
When you want to do a full text search, the performance was really bad from majority of the participants and we were able to.

Identify pitfalls and bottlenecks in the current design of the so because the dashboard was what knew to everyone, to the people who were using it, and also for the people who designed them so we could in the process of doing this we could also streamline you know how the visualization was and how things how things could be improved there so.
The benefits and impacts of this for the Semantic Web Company where now the system is running, so this is real in the sense that this is an implementation in progress.
I mean implementation in the running the current version of pool Party uses this and they are now getting structured data from all their requirements and issues.

So the benefits that it has had is that the you know we've seen that ontologies can be used to create merged repositories of requirements and customer feedback and the consolidate the consolidated pool party experiences actually.
A key factor for the Semantic Web company in terms of, you know, providing them nice saving of resources so that they can improve their product development lifecycles.

The data integration has also enabled the mining of intense, so now they can go back and see why a certain requirement was implemented in a certain way and the issues and the comments you know the various arguments and the assumptions and the you risztics behind those solutions and.
It has also made the flow of customer requirements into the system faster.
So.
So basically there is the well I can't talk much about future work because this is now being extensively tested since this is live and running as part of their product.

And to summarize what I have presented today is I've shown how in a real world setting for a product like pool party where you know the customer requirements flowing in all the time developers are working on implementing the issues raised by the customer, how?
Ontologies can be used to integrate the information and provide a much better way of linking and structuring data so that searching over that information becomes easier.
The evaluated this on an industrial soft engineering use case and we have seen an impressive 50% reduction in the time that it takes to search over the aggregated information.
The evaluation also showed us the limitations of.
The full text search implementation that is currently.
That has been done for the for the dashboard, so thank you very much for listening and I'm happy to take any questions you have.
